title: 112_hr1919
content: The Act may be cited as the "Bleeding Disorder Screening, Awareness, and Further Education (SAFE) Act of 2011". The Congress finds that millions of Americans may have an inherited bleeding disorder, with Von Willebrand Disease being the most common. Many remain undiagnosed due to outdated diagnostic methods. Adolescents may start experiencing symptoms, but often live with chronic health risks without realizing they have a bleeding disorder. Improved diagnosis of bleeding disorders, through expanded screening of adolescents, improved physician awareness, and additional research, could prevent unnecessary hysterectomies and improve the quality of life for millions of Americans. ADOLESCENT SCREENING PROGRAMS. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will develop a screening questionnaire for diagnosing bleeding disorders in adolescents and young adults. This questionnaire will be widely disseminated and implemented in adolescent populations to improve diagnosis and prevent unnecessary procedures. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will prioritize grants for screening high school and college students for bleeding disorders. Technical assistance may be provided for grant recipients. Appropriations are authorized for implementation. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2012 through 2016. SEC. 4. INCREASING AWARENESS AMONG HEALTH PROFESSIONALS. The Secretary will conduct an education campaign to raise awareness about bleeding disorders among health professionals, with priority given to those caring for adolescents and obstetricians/gynecologists. The Secretary may provide technical assistance to grant recipients for planning and implementing activities. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2012 through 2016. SEC. 5. RESEARCH AND SURVEILLANCE. The Secretary will award grants to entities to enhance research on diagnosing bleeding disorders, determine prevalence in the general population, identify symptoms and risk factors, and improve quality of life for women with bleeding disorders. The Secretary may provide technical assistance to grant recipients for planning and implementing activities related to bleeding disorders in women. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2012 through 2016. The Secretary may provide technical assistance to grant recipients for activities related to bleeding disorders in women. The Secretary shall submit a report to Congress within 5 years of this Act's enactment, detailing activities related to bleeding disorder screening, health professional education, and surveillance. The report must include an assessment of progress, the number of students screened for bleeding disorders, and the healthcare professionals educated on bleeding disorders. The report to Congress within 5 years of the Act's enactment will detail bleeding disorder activities, including education and surveillance. Recommendations will be made to improve screening and education programs to increase diagnostic rates and reduce the burden of bleeding disorders. Recommendations will be made to improve screening and education programs to increase diagnostic rates and reduce the burden of bleeding disorders. It will also identify organizations and programs that have effectively increased bleeding disorder screening rates and describe services provided by hemophilia treatment centers. The report to Congress within 5 years of the Act's enactment will detail bleeding disorder activities, including education, surveillance, recommendations for future research, and interventions. The term "State" in this Act includes the District of Columbia and any commonwealth, territory, or possession of the United States.
